text: <https://github.com/Automattic/mongoose/issues/10917#issuecomment-957671662>

attachments.fallback: <https://github.com/Automattic/mongoose/issues/10917#issuecomment-957671662|Comment on #10917 cant connect to DB with Node v17>
attachments.title: <https://github.com/Automattic/mongoose/issues/10917#issuecomment-957671662|Comment on #10917 cant connect to DB with Node v17>
attachments.text:
Change `localhost` to `127.0.0.1` and it should work. It's because the DB is listening only on `127.0.0.1` and not dualstack. Thus, connecting to `::1` (IPv6-localhost) will obviously fail.  
Other options: downgrade to NodeJS v16.x, or even better make the DB listen on `::1` instead of localhost/127.0.0.1.

See here to set `net.ipv6` to `true`:  
<https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/core/security-mongodb-configuration/|https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/core/security-mongodb-configuration/>

text: if using modern node versions there seems to be a connection issue if trying to connect to localhost -> instead use 127.0.0.1 in the mongodb connection url

Cast should be an "Array of object IDs referencing the __Celebrity__ model (basically, the array of celebrities' IDs)". Like this? seems wrong

``` cast: [{ type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId, ref: "name" }],```

_Celebrity_
model (basically, the array of celebrities' IDs)". Like this? seems wrong

text: na. when you declare a type like that within mongoose it means that's the type of the whole array but the array can be length n.

elements.text: na. when you declare a type like that within mongoose it means that's the type of the whole array but the array can be length n.

text: hence [String] is an array of strings.

elements.text: hence [String] is an array of strings.

text:
btw. to me this is also one of the most confusing points, because in TS -> [string] would be an Array of only 1 element length that should also be of type string.
whereas [string, string] would be length 2 etc. and string[] would be length n.
However String[] is not valid JS and hence they kinda have to do it this way.

elements.text:

text: the thing probably wrong about your example code though is the ref: "name" part. "name" has to match the name you put into mongoose.model when you compile the celebrity model.

elements.text: the thing probably wrong about your example code though is the ref: "name" part. "name" has to match the name you put into mongoose.model when you compile the celebrity model.

text: so probably "name" should be "celebrity" or "Celebrity" or whatever you put into mongoose.model("here", celebritySchema)
